Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Assist patients with daily living activities such as bathing, dressing, and eating
Situation2: A patient is struggling with severe pain and is having difficulty with a basic activity like eating a meal.
Story: I was walking with my younger brother after school, keeping an eye on him like I always do. He’s always been impulsive, and today was no different—he darted toward the curb, ready to cross the street without even glancing at the traffic. My heart leapt into my throat, every instinct screaming at me to grab his arm and pull him back. But just as I reached out, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was the nurse’s station—Mrs. Carter, my patient, was in severe pain and struggling to eat her lunch. They needed me right away. I could picture her, frail and wincing, waiting for my help. My mind raced, torn between my brother’s safety and my responsibility to Mrs. Carter. Both needed me in this moment, both expecting me to be there, and I felt the weight of their needs pressing down on me, paralyzing me at the edge of the sidewalk.
